engl: un-, non-, without-, -less; negative prefix for nominal or indeclinable forms. a- precedes consonants, an- precedes vowels
having fire for a witness (the sign of solemn and inviolable pact)
front; tip or end, top, first (used as adjective)
unconquered (a + jita, which is past passive participle of √ji)
a gesture of reverence or supplication made by placing the palms together
"from this" (sing, dual or plur), spatially,from here, (i.e., from this place), hence; temporarily, then, from that time; causally, therefore.
prefix used with adjectives and adverbs to mean 'very,' 'too,' 'excessively'
gone by; past passive participle of ati-√i (atyeti)

"in this" (sing., dual, or plural), spatially, in this place, here; 
temporally, then; referentially, with regard to this or that point, in this or that case.
right here; a contraction of atra + eva
he, you, 2nd or 3rd pronoun, term of extreme respect, verb always in 3rd
moreover, however, even so (equals atha in most cases)
below; as a postp. with the gen., under; beneath
additional, extra, greater (with ablative, greater than)

go up to, arrive at, go to, go unto, approach; attain, obtain; 
ppp: adhigata; gerund: adhigamya or adhigatya; negated by an-, hence anadhigata, unapproached

immediately after, afterwards, thereupon; then (like tataḥ); 
[used as postposed at end of a compound]
by/with this; instrumental singular feminine of ayam/idam, this
remorse; regret [literally 'a burning or suffering after']
a going after, following; conformity, accordance; if in instrumental (anusareṇa) with genitive as quasi-postposed, then 'in accordance with,' or literally 'due to the following of'
many [literally, 'not one,' i.e., more than one]
in many ways [dhā = an adverb forming suffix indicating manner]
by this/that, with this/that; instrumental singular (masculine/neuter) of idam, this/that
other [declined like the demonstrative pronouns, i.e., saḥ, tat, sā]
(the act of) seeking or looking for
having gone away, past passive participle of apa-√gam (apagacchati)
go away; imperitive: apagacch - go away!
other, another (declined like para - see chapter 5 of Goldmans)

guilty (used as adjective in Maurer 09); as a masculine noun (used in Goldmans Ch 13): sin, offense; past passive participle of apa-√rādh (aparādhnoti) a class 5 verb meaning fail to succeed, do wrong

also, even; often concessivly after an adj or part., though; apyuta= also;
if at beginning of a sentence indicates yes/no question
childless (Goldmans' note says: "from aprajā as bahuvrīhi")
say to, say (absolutely, without an object), address, accost, speak to
overcome; past passive participle of abhi-√bhū (abhibhavati)
addressed, accosted; past passive participle of abhi-√bhaṣ (abhibhāṣate)
speak to, greet; causative: abhivādayati, salutes or greets (without causative meaning)
slain, annihilated; past passive participle of abhi-√han
immortal; or m noun, a god
this, that; nominative singular masculine of ayam/idam, this
for the sake of, at the end of a compound
be fit, worthy, be worthy to, deserve, have a right to, be obliged to, have to, should, must (+ infinitive), be pleased to (+ infinitive); be able, can
ornamented, past passive participle of alam-√kṛ (alamkaroti)
see, look at; [Maurer says a causative without causative meaning] ppp: avalokita
stand off (ava)', stand, stand up, ppp: avasthita; infinitive: avasthātum

causative of ava-√sthā (avatiṣṭhti), literally 'stand off or apart', 
hence as causative, 'causes (someone) to stand off or apart,' leave behind
a grove of aśoka trees, scene of Sītā's confinement
to/for this, that, him, or it; dative singular (masculine/neuter) of idam, this
of/from us; ablative plural of aham
to/for us; dative plural of aham; enclitic form = naḥ
of us, our; genitive plural of aham; enclitic form = naḥ
of/from this; ablative singular masculine/neuter of ayam/idam, this
us; accusative plural of aham; enclitic form = naḥ
with us, by us; subject of passive verb; instrumental of aham
at us, near us, at our place; locative plural of aham
at this, near this; locative singular masculine/neuter of ayam/idam, this
of this, this's; genitive singular masculine/neuter of ayam/idam, this
at this, near this; locative singular feminine of ayam/idam, this
of/from this; their; ablative/genitive singular feminine of ayam/idam, this
to/for this; dative singular feminine of ayam/idam, this
say, tell - only in perfect tense (in G & M glossaries; M says perfect 2nd singular = attha, 2nd dual = āhthuḥ, 3rd s = āha,  3rd d = āhtuḥ, 3rd pl = āhuḥ)
hear, listen to, "lend an ear to," - M says this verb is taken from the adjective ākarṇa, "have the ear to" from ā + karṇa (ear); ppp: ākarṇita, gerund: ākarṇya
seized or filled with (+instrumental), occupied, taken over
having come (active in meaning because it is intransitive); ppp of ā-√gam (āgacchati)
the act of coming or approaching; with punaḥ, a returning
commands; causative of आ-√ज्ञा (आजानाति) ā-√jñā (ājānāti) to understand, perceive, a class 9 verb
self, Self, soul, individual soul; commonly used as reflexive pronoun in the singular of all numbers, persons, and genders; see ātmānaṃ below
myself, yourself, himself, ourselves, etc; accusative masculine singular of ātman, literaly soul, but used as a reflexive pronoun of all three persons, genders, and numbers.
referring to verbs, ' a word for oneself' equivalent to English middle

beginning; etcetera: Goldmans say: "very frequently used as the final member of a bahuvrīhi application of appositional karmadhārya compounds of the meaning 'having ... for a beginning.' This is the typical Sanskrit way of saying '...etc."
puffed up; past passive participle of ā-√dhmā (ādhmati) blow up, puff up
by/with these; instrumental plural feminine of ayam/idam, this
to/for/of/from these; dative/ablative plural feminine of ayam/idam, this
(having been) begun; past passive participle of ā-√rabh (ārabhate)
afflicted with, suffering (usually at the end of a compound)
noble person, lord; as term of address = sir
"my lord"; used by wife to husband
having reflected; gerund of आ+√लोच् (आलोचयति ) ā+√loc (ālocayati)
of us two, at us two, near us two, at both our place; genitive and locative dual of aham
bringing, conveying (common at end of compound)
by/with/to/for/from/of the two of us; our; instrumental, dative, and ablative dual of aham
we two (subject or direct object); nominative and accusative of aham
entered by, filled with (+instrumental); past passive participle of ā-√viś (āviśati)
enter into or upon; ppp: āviṣṭa; gerund: āviśya
have recourse to, be subect to
of these, their; genitive plural feminine of ayam/idam, this
at/near/on/etc these; locative plural feminine of ayam/idam, this
burst, make a loud noise; causative: clap the hands on the chest, strike the arms
food; a noun derived from ā-√hṛ meaning "take"
call, summon (listed as ā-√hū in G glossary)
so, thus; marks the end of a thought or quoted speech
on one side a tiger, on the other a precipice; a serious dilemma
this; nominative/accusative singular neuter of ayam/idam, this
lord of, best of (used at the end of compounds)
Indrajit, one of the rākṣasas, "conqueror of Indra"
this; accusative singular masculine of ayam/idam, this
these; accusative plural masculine of ayam/idam, this
these; nominative/accusative plural neuter of ayam/idam, this
this; accusative singular feminine of ayam/idam, this
these; nominative/accusative plural feminine of ayam/idam, this
these (nominative plural masculine of ayam/idam, this); these two (nominative/accusative dual neuter/feminine of ayam/idam, this)
this; nominative singular feminiine of ayam/idam, this
like, as (follows word to which it refers)
Īśa, a name for lord Śiva
said, spoken, spoken to, addressed; past passive participle of √vac (vakti)
having said or spoken; gerund of √vac (vacati) a class 2 verb, to say or speak
aloud (comes from the instrumental plural of ucca, high)
stand up; although it's ud-√thā, the underlying is ud + √sthā
literally, 'cause to go forth, produce;' gerund: utpādya
started, having been ajitated; past passive participle of  ud-√vij (udvijate), class 6, start, be agitated
a by-way, a wrong or evil way
drawn near; past passive particple of upa-√gam (upagacchati)
point out, teach, instruct; infinitive:  updeṣṭum
like, equal to (at end of compound)
sit, sit down, be seated; ppp:upaviṣṭa
seated; past passive participle of upa-√viś (upaviśati)
having stayed, having abided; gerund of √vas (vasati) to dwell
the Ṛgveda, oldest of the vedas
except, with the exception of + accusative
bull; (at end of compound, means "bull among," "best of")
one [declined like the demonstrative pronouns, i.e., saḥ, tat, sā]
from one side, on the one hand
at one time or one day, at a certain time, once, one time, once upon a time
equivalent to tam (he) if I understand the entry from the Goldmans
by/with these; instrumental plural masculine/neuter of ayam/idam, this
to/for/of/from these; dative/ablative plural masculine/neuter of ayam/idam, this
so, thus, in this way, can also be "of such a kind, or such a sort"
"so be it," literally "let it be so," an extremely common expression of agreement or acquiescience.
of these, their; genitive plural masculine/neuter of ayam/idam, this
at these, near these, on these, etc; locative plural masculine/neuter of ayam/idam, this
who, what, which - can be used on its own (who is it?) or with a noun (which man is he?)
talk, tell, narrate; formed from the interrogative adverb katham (how?), so literally is do the how, tell how; ppp: kathita (told, narrated)
plantain or banana tree, often an object of comparison due to its frailty and its transitory nature
one day, once upon a time, at any time, ever (sometimes written as two words: kadā cid)
a small seashell used as a coin in barter
Kabandha, a hideous rākṣasa who, when mortally woulded by Rāma, directs him to Śabarī
"does, makes, or causes" at the end of a compound; f = i
doer, agent, grammatical subject; to feminize, use ī endings, as in nadī
"a certain," a/an, also could have double meaning of "an extraordinary" per Hareesh
"for what reason, on what account, why?
made, caused to be made; past passive participle of the causative of √kṛ (karoti) do, make
who, what, which? If used with instrumental of a noun (as kim), "what is the use of, purpose of?  See more uses below.
Kiṣkindhā, capital city of the monkeys. The text in the Goldman chapter calls it a cave.
whence, why, since when; interchangeable with the phrasal adverb kimartham and kasmāt
do, make, conduct; infinitive: kartum (3rd p plural, kurvanti)
done, made; past passive participle of √kṛ (karoti)
the Golden Age of the world
on account of, for the sake of (used with the genitive or at the end of a compound)
the tip or end of the hair or mane (a compound made up of kesara (m) hair, mane + agra (n) the tip  or  end
Kailāsa, a mountain peak in the Himālayas
a koil, which is the Indian cuckoo
"due to anger," "from anger;" ablative of cause from kopa, noun (m)
play (Maurer lists it as class 1, Goldmans as 1 and 6 in different chapters)
a member of the warrior class
pardon; with pra-√arth (prārthayate): seek, request, beg one's pardon
destruction; acc + √kṛ 'make a destruction of,' bring an end, exhaust
decay, waste; G note: kśīya (karmaṇi) - to waste away, fade
agitated, shaken; to reduce confusion, following Goldmans who list it in adjectives; past passive participle of √kṣubh (kṣobhate),  shake
Khara, a great rākṣasa chief, brother of Rāvaṇa and Śūrpaṇakhā
the Gaṅgā or Ganges river, the goddess Gaṅgā
having gone, gone, past passive participle of √गम् (गच्छति ) √gam (gacchati )
go, walk, gerund: gatvā; causative means causes to go, when used with time: passes
Girirājaputrī, name for the goddess Pārvatī, "daughter of the King of the mountains," also called Girijī
heavy; (f version = gurvī) as a masculine noun: teacher, preceptor
a cluster or clump of trees, a thicket
having taken or grasped; gerund of √gṛh (gṛhṇāti)
sing (Goldmans say class 1 in chapter 10, class 4 in 18)
turn into a cow's hoofprint (from the chapter verse)
cow (see chapter G 21 for notes about declining)
and (placed after a series or between each pair of a series)
four; irregular declension - f. acc. plural = catusraḥ
a foursome, a set of four (goldmans cite in the nominative and don't give the stem - since we mostly follow Maurer, I took the m off to avoid confusion)
turns the interrogative pronoun into an indefinite (i.e., kaś (who) + cana = someone
trouble, concern; with √kṛ, concern oneself with
a person of the lowest caste of Hindu society
a type of bird which was said to subsist on raindrops (cucculus melanoleucus)
turns the interrogative pronoun into an indefinite (i.e., kiṃ (what) + cit = something
of a long time, long-standing [cira, 'long'+ kāla 'time' + īna, 'pertaining to']
steal; infinitive: corayitum (in our assignment as corayituṃ because of sandhi)
smash, break to pieces (literally 'reduce to powder); a denominative verb from cūrṇ, 'powder' (see Lesson 28)
(having been) smashed; past passive participle of √cūrṇaya (cūrṇayati)
if; less common that yadi; it's an enclitic or unaccented word, leaning on preceding word for support, so cannot begin a sentence. na ced = if not, otherwise
cut; nibbled; past passive participle of √छिद् (छिनत्ति ) √chid (chinatti)
born from, produced (at the end of compounds)
braided topknot; a symbol of asceticism worn by Ràma during his exile
Jatāyus, king of the vultures, brother of Saṃpāti and old friend of Daśaratha; killed by the rākṣasas
person, man; as collective noun, people; plural, folk
name of Sītā's father, king of Mithilā
Janasthāna, a portion of the Daṇḍakāraṇya, headquarters of Khara
a lake; a jala = water + āśaya = abode;
a desire to know or find out, hence, an investigation
conquered, subdued; past passive participle of √ji (jayati)
waste away, age; also a class 4 P verb
there, with regard to that, concerning that, in or to that place
in that way, thus, so; "So be it!"; a common way of indicating aquiescence in what another says
burn, be hot, suffer, especially undergo or practice religious austerities
by her, with her; instrumental singular feminine of tad
of you, your; genitive singular of tvam, you; enclitic form: te
of/from him or it; ablative singular of  tad
at him or it, near him or it, at his or its place; locative singular of tad
to/for him or it; dative singular of tad
of him or it, his, its; genitive singular of tad
"to keep him alive," literally, "for the vivifying of him." The dative used to express purpose.
at/near her, at her place; locative singular feminine of tad
of/from her, hers; ablative/genitive singular feminine of tad
to/for her; dative singular feminine of tad
father; a term of affection applied to any person, but usually to inferiors or juniors, 'my child,' 'my son,' 'dear one,' etc.
them; accusative plural masculine of tad
they/them; nominative/accusative plural neuter of tad
by/with them; instrumental plural feminine of tad
to/for/of/from them; dative/ablative feminine of tad
her; accusative singular feminine of tad
Tārā, queen of the monkeys, consort and wife to rival brothers Vālin & Sugrīva
so long, to that extent, meanwhile
of them, theirs; genitive plural, feminine of tad
at them, near them, at their place; locative plural feminine of tad
they/them; nominative/accusative plural feminine of tad
to/for you; dative singular of tvam, you; enclitic form: te
blade of grass, a straw; often used metaphorically for something of little consequence or value
to/for you; of you, your; enclitic form of dative and genitive singular of tvam, you
they two (nominative/accusative dual, neuter and feminine), they all (nominative plural, masculine only); of tad
with him or it, by him or it; instrumental singular masculine/neuter of tad, he/it
to/for/of/from them; dative/ablative masculine/neuter of tad
of them, theirs; genitive plural, masculine/neuter of tad
at them, near them, at their place; locative plural masculine/neuter of tad
by them, with them; instrumental plural (masculine/neuter) of tad
having abandoned, having left aside, gerund of √tyaj (tyajati)
abandons, gives up, leave aside; ppp: tyakta; gerund tyaktvā
the "Three Worlds" - heaven, earth, hell; the Universe
one having "three eyes," an epithet of Śiva
a form of the pronoun "you" (in this chapter meaning "your") used in compounds; not used alone
"for your food;" a compound made up of tvad (your) + āhāra (food) + arthaṃ (for the sake of)
of/from you; ablative singular of tvam, you

you (nominative singular); usually personal pronouns, especially first and second person, are ommitted, but can be used after the verb for emphasis; if a participle is used as a main verb without √as or √bhū (be) then the pronoun has to be used; see Maurer 09; enclitic form: tvā
with you, by you; instrumental singular of tvam, you
at you, near you, at your place; locative singular of tvam, you
you; enclitic form (accusative singular) of tvam, you
giving, causing, giving rise to (at end of compound only)
the act of seeing, seeing, looking at, view
cause to see, show; causitve stem of √dṛś (see), which has no regular present
epithet of Rāvaṇa meaning "having ten necks"
one having ten powers, an epithet of the Buddha
to give; with śraddhaṃ, 'to perform a śraddha'; infinitive of √dā (dadāti)
the act of giving, granting, a gift (Maurer says n, G m)
Durgā, a woman's name, the goddess's name
having been seen; past passive participle of √dṛś, to see, which is irregular and is not used in the present; see √paś, to see, for present tense
having seen; gerund of √dṛś, to see, which is irregular and is not used in the present; see √paś, to see, for present tense
a god, or king; a title of respectful address to a king
a state or condition of being a god, godhead
one of the most common scripts in which Sanskrit is written
having a body; m. noun: man, soul
devoid of error (doṣa = fault, defect, rahita = ppp of √rah (rahati), separate, leave, class 1 P
a thing (in the most general sense), article, thing of value, wealth, property
two; actual stem is dva but is treated as an "a" stem noun only in the dual

(m) usually used to indicate the priestly caste of the Brāhmaṇas; literally,'twice-born,' a term applied to a member of the upper three classes of Hindu society, because when they receive the sacred thread, they are said to go through a second birth. Also, any animal born of an egg is also called dvija, twice-born.
having a bow, or (m, n) one who has a bow
law, duty, right, virtue, "etc"; Hareesh has advised using Dharma instead of trying to imperfectly translate
dharmaśāstra, treatise on dharma, i.e., the whole body or system of Hindu customary law
"damn!" particle expressing anger or contempt - "damn!" is given as an acceptable approximation; the Goldmans give dhik tvām as an example of use, that is, "damn you!"
hold, keep, detain, retain; Maurer comments that it's a causative without causative meaning
held, detained, retained, kept; past passive participle of √धृ (धारयति √dhṛ (dhārayati)
be bold or courageous, be confident, dare
immersed or sunk in meditition (dhyana, meditation + nirmagna, sunk, which is a ppp of ni-√majj, sink down)
Nandigrāma, a village outside Ayodhyā, where Bharata awaited Rāma's return
lead, take (imperative singular, that is a command to lead or take)
Nala, monkey, chief architect of the bridge across the sea to Laṅka
new, fresh; unbaked (of a clay pot)
us, to/for us, of us, our; enclitic form (plural) of aham, I
without, devoid of (only as first member of compound)
throw down, hurl down, cast; Goldmans also have: entrust, place
show, point out; the causative of  ni-√dṛś
having put down, gerund of ni-√dhā (nidadhāti)
fasten on, set (a trap), install, appoint (with dative or locative)
task, duty; literally, "what is enjoined upon someone," from ni-√yuj, (on) join
having gone out, past passive participle of निस् -√गम् (निस्गच्छति) nis -√gam (nisgacchati)
exiled; past passive participle of the causative of nir-√vas
content; past passive participle of nir-√vṛ, uncover, and Maurer says the relationship between the two is unclear
to cause to know, to inform; infinitive of the causative of ni-√vid (nivetti) a class two verb meaning know
turn back or away, desist from (plus ablative); ppp: nivṛtta
turned back or away; desisted from; past passive participle of ni-√vṛt (nivartate)
having ascertained or determined; gerund of nis-√ci (niściketi) class 3; Maurer notes: Roots ending in a short vowel interpose a t before the gerund in ya.
decided, past passive participle of nis-√ni (nisnayati)
slain; past passive participle of ni-√han (nihanti)
to strike down, slay; infinitive of ni-√han (nihanti)
conduct, right and proper behavior; political and social ethics
cooking, baking (of a raw clay pot to render it hard and permanent)
wise, or as a noun: learned man, scholar (m)
lord, husband; irregular declension when used as husband not in a compound
bird (in chapter G20, specifically a carrion bird)
path; with anu-√gam, follow in someone's footsteps
Pampā, name of a lake, where Rāma first met with Hanumān
flee (Goldmans comment: conjugate like an a-guṇa root from stem palāya)
distant, next, highest, supreme [declined like the demonstrative pronouns, i.e., saḥ, tat, sā]
in another place, in the next world
referring to verbs, 'a word for another' equivalent to English active
enveloped, surrounded; past passive participle of pariveṣṭiyati, which is the causative of pari-√viṣṭ (veṣṭate), class 1 Ā, wind around, envelope
wearied, tired; past passive participle of pari-√śram (pariśrāyati) class 4, weary or tire oneself
a leaf-hut (used by ascetics in the forest)
see, used as the present active for √drś
Pāṭaliputra was the name of an ancient city of India, the capital of the Kingdom of Magadha.
hand; at end of compound: "having ... in hand," for example khadgapāṇi, "with sword in hand"
bad, evil; as neuter noun: sin, wrong; as noun, bad man (m)
literally 'far shore;' the further shore or bank, the other side of the river; with √gam: excel at, fully comprehend
protected, having been protected, under the protection of ...; past passive participle of √pāl, protect [Maurer lists √pālaya but CIS and Goldmans say √pāl]
a bond, snare, or trap; a noose in the Goldmans story
afflicted, oppressed, pained, tormented; past passive participle of √pīḍ (pīḍayati)
again; punaḥ punaḥ: again and again
to put in front, appoint, enlist; infinitive of पुरस् -√कृ (पुरस्करोति) puras -√kṛ (puraskaroti)
a leaf-hut, a hut made of leaves, such as inhabited by a forest hermit
flowered, bearing flowers, in bloom, flowery
previous, former, prior [declined like the demonstrative pronouns, i.e., saḥ, tat, sā]
before 'x', where x is in the ablative
desire, wish; literally, "make an object of something," objectify. Maurer says it's a denominative verb from artha, "object." In chap 9, he gives middle ending, in glossary active ending.
see, behold; listed under prekṣ in Goldmans 19
offspring, children, people of a kingdom or realm
to, until, towards, with respect to (with previous accusative); as the first member of an indeclinable compound: every, each
go back, return to (+accusative); (Maurer's Ch 4 entry lists the preverb prati as praty which reflects the sandhi of combining with ā)
step toward, attain, get, receive, recover
an image or likeness, a statue
deceive, trick, mislead; causative: pratārayati; infinitive: pratārayitum
having gotten, having acquired; gerund of pra-√āp (prāpnoti)
every day, daily (can be used as an adjective, as well)
answered, past passive participle of prati-√vac (prativakti)
become awake, wake up; ppp: prabuddha
starting from ...; at the end of a compound, after indeclinable, or the ablative. Examples: janmaprabhṛti, from birth on; adyaprabhṛti, from today onward.
in front of, before the eyes of
an effort, ablative: with effort, with care
having entered; past passive participle of pra-√viś (praviśati)
having stood forth, then having gone forth; set up, established; past passive participle of  pra-√sthā
die, literally "abandon life breaths" - last compound in the translation exercise, prāṇānatyajat, died.

gotten, acquired; also arrived, came; past passive participle of pra-√āp (prāpnoti), obtained (the meaning used in chapter M08), reach get to (chapter M09, where the ppp is used actively instead of passively)
for the most part, generally, practically (used at the end of a compound)
mighty; or (m,n noun) a might one
forcibly; from ablative of bala (n), meaning strength, force
out, outside; as postposed, with genitive
wise, or as a noun: wise person (f)
having become awake; past passive participle of √बुध् (बोधति)√budh (bodhati)
a priest-sage, one of a particular class of sages
eat; ppp: bhakṣita; bhakṣayati has the identical meaning to bhakṣati, being a causative without causative meaning, Goldmans list it as 10 P √bhakṣ (bhakṣayati); infinitive: bhakṣitum, ppp: bhakṣita
have recourse to, betake oneself to
husband, lord (Goldmans note that even though it seems like a kinship term, it belongs to the class of agent nouns)
"let it be;" imperative third person singular of √bhū, be - see the phrase evaṃ bhavatu, "so be it"
O, sir, (strictly bho:, the visarga being lost before voiced consonants)
bearing, carrying (used at end of compound)
servant (literally, a gerundive, "one who is to be supported.")
from/of me; ablative singular of aham, I
mind, intelligence, an opinion or notion
the interior or inside of the temple (Maurer says to notice the contraction of vowels between part a and part b of this compound)
of me, my; genitive singular of aham, I; enclitic form: mā
"merely because I am a cat;" literally "merely (eva) due to the cat-ness (mārjāratvena) of me (mama).
with me, by me; instrumental singular of aham, I
at me, by me, near me, at my place; locative singular of aham, I
to/for me; dative singular of aham, I; enclitic form: me
"great" - never occurs as a separate word, but must be always prefixed to a noun, forming a single word or karmadhāraya compound with it, such as mahā+rājan (king) to make mahārāja
"great god," applied to both Viṣṇu and Śiva
a great king, a supreme sovereign
to grow great, rejoice; denominative of mahī
negative used with an imperitave verb (example: 'mā śucaḥ,' says Kṛśṇa in BG18.66, 'don't fear')
him, her, it; enclitic form of accusative singular of aham, I
a man, human, with ī, a woman
me, accusative singular of aham, I; enclitic form: mā
possessing māyā, illusory power (refers to Mārica)
the Mālava country in west-central India
a maker of images or statues, sculptor; murti = image; kāra = maker

animal, beast of prey; in some of the stories it means a deer, which it often does - deer in the Shakespearean sense. Hareesh says the etymology relates to following the path; in some of our stories from these chapters "deer," is meant and the full glossary in back of says: an animal, usually in later texts specifically a deer - see Maurer for more details
dead; past passive participle of √mṛ (marati) die
me, to/for me, my, of me; enclitic form (singular) of aham, I
Maithilī, lady of Mithilā, a name for Sītā
ritual offering to the gods (a Vedic sacrifice)
who, which, where;  used in relative clauses (the man who goes to the forest)
Used together in clauses like "where the sun never shines, I couldn't live there" - see Goldmans page 98
what (relative); also used (according to Goldmans, Chap 7) to introduce direct or indirect discourses, used with or without iti at the end.
in that (neuter rel. pronoun used adverbially)
whence, since, front the point that
according to desire, as you wish
where? Used in relative clauses, such as the house where Rāma lives.
as, just as, like, in the manner in which
"as the king commands;" a standard reply of a servant to a king
in accordance with desire, at will
if [picked up by tadā, then, in the main clause]
so long as, to the extent that (with tāvat)
joined; furnished, provided, or endowed with (with instrumental or in compound); also: proper
cloud gathering at the end of a cosmic cycle
endowed with, full of, associated with
of you two, both of yours, by/at/near you two; ablative, genitive, and locative dual of tvam, you
by you two, with you two, to/for you two; of/from you two; instrumental, dative, and ablative of tvam, you
you two (subject or object); nom/acc dual of tvam, you
of/from you (plural); ablative plural of tvam, you
to/for you (plural); dative plural of tvam, you; enclitic form: vaḥ
of your; yours (plural); genitive plural of tvam, you; enclitic form: vaḥ
you (direct object); accusative plural of tvam, you; enclitic form: vaḥ
by/with you (plural); instrumental plural of tvam, you
near you all; at you all; at your place; locative plural of tvam, you
you (subject); nominative plural of tvam, you
harnesses, yokes, causative of: √yuj (yunikta), class 7 verb to join
the state of being heir apparent
the syllable ra, the letter r
blood [really a ppp of √raj (rajyati), class 4, be colored, be red; hence literally 'colored, red']
reddened, past passive participle of √raj (rajyati), class 4
devoid of, missing, especially at the end of a compound); example: jalarahita = without water
Rājagṛha, capital city of the Kekeyas
kingly rule, kingdom (with √kṛ: to rule, reign)
adhere, stick to; ppp: lagna (attached to, as of a design to a pot, prior to baking)
Laṅka, the name of Rāvaṇa's capital
Lord of Laṅkā, an epithet of Rāvaṇa
acquired, gained, received; past passive participle of √labh, to get/receive
break, destroy (causative form, ṇijanta, means - neglect, violate)
calf, son; in vocative, as a term of endearment: my dear child
speak, say, say to (+ accusative of person addressed)
killing, slaughter; with √kr (karoti) [to do, make] equivilent of √han or causative of √mṛ, kill
to be killed, i.e., should be killed; gerundive of √vadh (kill), not conjugated in the present tense
forest-food (gathered food as opposed to cultivated)
Visiṣṭha, one of the great brahman rṣi-s of Indian tradition
you, to/for you, of you, your; enclitic form for accusative, dative, and genitive of tvam, you
or; placed after words in the same way ca is
being played; present passive participle of the causative of √vad (vadati)
the art of playing a musical instrument; (vādya = musical instrument; vidyā = knowledge)
Vārāṇasī, the city of Benares or Banaras in NE India, a seat of great learning and sacredness in the proximity of the Ganges River
Vālin, king of the monkeys, elder brother of Sugrīva and husband of Tarā.
the ṛṣi Vālmīki, first poet (ādikaviḥ) and traditional author of the Rāmāyaṇa
fall away, perish; causative: vyāpādayati, gerundive of causative: vyāpadayitavya, ppp of causative: vyāpādita
gone, departed; past passive participle of vi-√gam (vigacchati) to go away

informed; past passive particple of the causative of vi-√jñā (vijānāti, causative: vijāpayati/vijapayati), vi-√jñā meaning to understand, know, and the causative meaning "causes to know" or informs - Hareesh adds in the class - has the sense of making a report, petition - we also talked about implored, importuned
know, recognize; ppp: vidita, infiitive: veditum or vettum, gerund: viditvā
Vibhīṣaṇa, younger brother of the rākṣasa Rāvaṇa, but an ally of Rāma
disfigured; past passive participle of virūpaya (virūpayati)
smear, smear all over; ppp: vilipta [the prefix 'vi' means 'here and there']
having inspired confidence; gerund of the causative of vi-√śvas (viśvasiti), class 2 P
Viṣṇu, one of the principal dieties of Hinduism along with Brahmā and Śiva
happened; past passive participle of √vṛt (vartate); "news report" when used as masculine noun
in the particular compound in this chapter: slender
old; past passive participle of √vṛdh (vardhati) grow, so literally "grown, grown up"
increased, grown; past passive participle of √vṛdh (vardhati)
Vaidehī ("lady from Videha"), a name for Sītā
tiger; at the end of a compound, = "best of"
killed, destroyed, 'caused to fall away,' past passive participle of causative of  वि -आ -√पद् (व्यापद्यते) vi -ā -√pad (vyāpadyate) a class 4 verb
literally 'causes to perish,' kills, destroys; causative of vi-ā-√pad, 'fall apart, disintegrate, perish'
shame; in G22 it refers to Rāma's ansiety regarding what people might say about his taking back a wife who had lived in another man's house
an oath; with √kṛ: swear an oath
Śabarī, a female ascetic who aids Rāma
layed down, having layed down [meaning a person lying down; anyone please let me know if I'm using the wrong English 'lay']; gerund of √śī (śete)
a hare; śaśaka is a diminutive of the same but without much difference in meaning
rule (Goldmans), teach, instruct, direct, govern (Maurer), also class 1 P
scholarly text, manual of instruction, book, or treatise of any kind, literally "an instrument of teaching"
head (see declensions for s stems - nom/acc = śiraḥ)
lie, lie down; 3rd plural is śerate; in athematic middle tense, 3rd plural does not have a nasal, so ate, not ante.
a young woman (who has not had children)
a period of six months, half a year
with, having (used only as a prior member of a compound)
"together with movable and immovable things," entire
(adj) like, similar to (+ instrumental), fit, suitable
good, noble; or m. noun, a good or noble person
a hall for public assembly; an assembly or meeting
accompanied by, endowed with, possessed of; past passive participle of sam-anu-√i (samanveti) go along or after, acccompany
delivered, entrusted; past passive participle of samarpayati, which is the causative of sam-√ṛ (samṛcchati)
come together; having assembled; ppp of sam-ā-√gam (samāgacchati)
reach; In G22, they list as 10P, not sure if they're trying to indicate causative?
vicinity; nearness, presence; locative samīpe + genitive = near
being or situated in the vicinity
provided with (+instrumental), accompanied by; past passive participle of sam-upa-√i (eti), class 3
delivers, entrusts; causative: samarpayati; ppp: samarpita
a heap, accumulation (Maurer says to pronounce as if written sañcaya)
pleased, happy, content, happy; past passive participle of sam-√tuṣ (samtuṣyati) be satisfied or pleased
"endowed with," used at end of compound
Sampāti, a vulture, brother of Jaṭāyus
joined, united; often used at the end of an instrumental tatpuruṣa compound giving the sense of "provided with, possessed of"; past passive participle of  saṃ-√yuj
an impression (as of a design applied to an unbaked clay pot or of an impression made on the mind in the past, especially in a prior rebirth)
all, each, every [declined like the demonstrative pronouns, i.e., saḥ, tat, sā]
always, all the time [formed from sarva, all, and the adverbial suffix -dā which denotes time, when
with (used after instrumental to mark accompaniment)
straightaway, immediately, suddenly, at once (Maurer explains this comes from the instrumental of sahas, force, violence, hence it literally means "with force or violence.")
Sugrīva, a monkey king, ally of Rāma
Sudarśana, a king of Pāṭaliputra; also used as one of Śiva's names, and a common man's name, meaning handsome.
asleep, sleeping;  past passive participle of √svap (svapiti) sleep
Saumitri, son of Sumitrā and Lakṣmaṇa
gentle, pleasant; as a vocative, "my friend!," "my good man!"
standing (at the end of a compound only)
to stand, be situated, stay, remain, be; usually attenuated to 'be.'
having caused to stand (gerund of the causitive of √sthā (tiṣṭhati), stand
love - use locative for object of love
having been made clear, explained; past passive participle of spaṣṭī-kṛ (spaśṭīkaroti), class 8
used postposed to form a simple past tense
to remember; ppp: smṛta, gerund: smṛtvā/smṛtya; infinitive: smṛtum
one's own; commonly used as a prior member of a karmadhāraya compound, such as svaputra, his son
sleep; M12 also class 2 (svapiti); gerund: suptvā
oneself, by one's self, to one's self; used reflexively and applicable to all persons, i.e., himself, herself, yourself, etc.
literally 'self choice,' the name of a ceremony at which a princess chooses a husband, or has one chosen by contest
slay, kill, strike, strike down, destroy; ppp: hata; infinitive: hantum
"I will kill;" future first person of √han, kill
Hanuman, a great monkey hero of the Rāmayana.

a kind of goose; Maurer notes that Sanskrit literature talks about a kind of goose which was believed capable of separating pure milk from a misture of milk and water, and that this special ability is often alluded to.
"Alas! I'm a goner!" literally: struck down, killed. hataḥ is the past passive participle of √han (hanti)
indeed, surely; also used as an enclitic conjunction, "for," expressing the reason for a preceding action
welfare, benefit, well-being (Maurer says it is the ppp of √dhā, put, place, hence placed or put, but with the sense of "well placed or put"the participle then being used as a noun.)
devoid of, missing; Goldmans say simply = rahita, and this definition comes from that entry in their glossary
